Course Title:		Meetings and Presentations in English 
Credit Hours:		2
Instructor’s Name:	Dr. Yun-Hua Yang
Contact E-Mail:	yhyang@ntut.edu.tw
Office: 	        General Education Building Rm.805 / Extension: 3941, 3901
Term Offered:		Spring, 2014
Required Text:    Essential Presentation Skills: Keywords, Phrases and Strategies by Ian Andrew Mckinnon 
                Guide to Making Every Meeting Matter by Harvard Business Onpoint Article Collection
Course Description: 	This course aims to enhance English-major students’ communicative competence with special emphasis on business presentations and meetings. The concentration of this course is two-fold: business presentations and business meetings.  By developing effective skills, strategies and tactful language use, students with high-intermediate proficiency level of English will be able to prepare as well as present verbal reports to achieve business goal. Students will also be expected to participate and conduct meetings productively. All student meeting/briefing/presentation sessions must be videotaped.(*1)
 
Course Requirements: 	Students’ responsibilities in this class include:
(1)	Presentations and mock meetings 
(2)	Submitting to the instructor a presenter’s dossier with inclusion of the outlined briefing/presentation. Students who fail to submit the dossier as scheduled forfeit the right to deliver the speech and hence receive zero points.  
(3)	Evaluating one’s own presentations: all briefings/presentations have to be videotaped by the student presenter. Student presenters are required to watch their own videotaped performance, observe their own presentations, and compile all evaluation for submission. Students are strongly advised to use their own videotaping devices. A complete electronic portfolio (on compact disc) needs to be established and submitted at the semester end.

scorePolicy:
Grading Policy: 	(1) Academic honesty is prioritized in this class. Students should learn that plagiarism will not be tolerated. Students will fail the course without contention once an incident of plagiarism is identified in their submitted writing or presented speech.  
(2) The grading components are as follows:
Attendance 20%   		Briefings/ Presentations  40% 
Mock meetings 20%	Final Exam (impromptu) 20%
